paper_title.en: Stability of a pair of planar counter-rotating vortices in a rectangular box

description.en: The stability and transition of a pair of planar counter-rotating vortices in a confined region are investigated numerically. Direct numerical simulations in a rectangular box: D = [0,2kpi] x [0, pi], where k is, an 'aspect ratio, are done with symmetric external forcing. A pair of steady symmetric counter-rotating vortices are generated under weak forcing while they become unstable with stronger forcing. Special attention is paid to the effect of the aspect-ratio k on the stability and the transition. It is found that a steady asymmetric pattern appears for k > k(0) approximate to 0.5 while an oscillating asymmetric pattern for k < k(0). In particular, the symmetric vortices become very stable around k = 0.5 (i.e. the square region). Linear stability analysis, of a model flow similar to the symmetric vortices generated in the numerical simulations gives the same tendency as the above findings. The results suggest that the singular property of the stability at k = k(0) approximate to 0.5 is mainly dependent on the aspect ratio k of the region but rather independent of the superficial difference of the vorticity distribution. (C) 2002 Published by The Japan Society of Fluid Mechanics and Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Stability of a pair of planar counter-rotating vortices in a rectangular box

description.en: The stability and transition of a pair of planar counter-rotating vortices in a confined region are investigated numerically. A pair of steady symmetric counter-rotating vortices are generated under weak forcing while they become unstable with stronger forcing. Special attention is paid to the effect of the aspect-ratio k on the stability and the transition. It is found that a steady asymmetric pattern appears for k > k(0) approximate to 0.5 while an oscillating asymmetric pattern for k < k(0). In particular, the symmetric vortices become very stable around k = 0.5 (i.e. the square region). The results suggest that the singular property of the stability at k = k(0) approximate to 0.5 is mainly dependent on the aspect ratio k of the region but rather independent of the superficial difference of the vorticity distribution. paper_title.en: Vortex merging, oscillation, and quasiperiodic structure in a linear array of elongated vortices

description.en: Linear stability and the secondary flow pattern of the rectangular cell flow, [Formula Presented] [Formula Presented] are investigated in an infinitely long array of the [Formula Presented] direction [Formula Presented] or various finite [Formula Presented] arrays [Formula Presented] on the assumption of a stress-free boundary condition on the lateral walls. The numerical results of the eigenvalue problems on the infinite array show that a mode representing a global circulating vortex in the whole region [Formula Presented] appears in the [Formula Presented]-elongated cases [Formula Presented] which confirm the secondary flow observed in Tabeling et al. [J. Fluid Mech. 213, 511 (1990)], while a mode representing quasiperiodic arrays of counter-rotating vortices appears in the [Formula Presented]-elongated cases [Formula Presented] at large critical Reynolds number. In large finite arrays the mode connected with those of the case [Formula Presented] appears for most cases while another (oscillatory) mode appears for vortices elongated in the [Formula Presented] direction. The parameter region of the oscillatory modes becomes wider when the system size [Formula Presented] becomes smaller. For a pair of counter-rotating vortices [Formula Presented] at the point [Formula Presented] between the regions of the two modes the critical Reynolds number takes an extreme large value. Analysis of a finite nonlinear system obtained by the Galerkin method shows the nonlinear saturation of the critical modes, though its results are in quantitative agreement with those of the linear stability in a limited region of [Formula Presented]. © 1998 The American Physical Society.

paper_title.en: Three-dimensional negative eddy viscosity effect on the onset of instability in some planar flows

description.en:
Three-dimensional linear stability of the rectangular cell flow Ψ=coskx cosy (0&lt
k&lt
1) to long-wave disturbances is investigated numerically. Owing to the spatial periodicity of the flow the disturbances take the form exp[σt+i(αkx+βy+γz)]F(kx,y) (0&lt
α&lt
0.5, 0&lt
β&lt
0.5, and 0&lt
γ&lt
), where F has the same periodicity as the main flow. It is found that the critical Reynolds number is determined by the three-dimensional large-scale modes in the range 0.55k0.71. The direction of the critical mode (α=0,βγ) is independent of the anisotropic parameter k. © 1995 The American Physical Society.
